advert.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (DEC. 1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Christmas accounts" <br><br> "Casio, it counts"</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert from Byte magazine (january 1977) said : <br><br> ...It gets its speed and power from a selected version of the new Z80 microprocessor that can operate at a 4 Mhz. clock rate (The Z-1 also lets you switch to 2 Mhz. to be compatible with older systems)...<br> ...The Z-1 offers you all kinds of peripherals and softwares. It uses the standard ''S100'' bus supported by over a dozen manufacturers. And all Cromemco peripherals (PROM memory and programmer, Ram memory, analog I/O, color TV interface, etc) just plug into the Z1's sockets...<br> ... The Z-1 comes completely assembled ans tested. It's a quality, commercial grade microcomputer. It is not available as a kit.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> US AD. JUNE 1983</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert said:<br><br><font color="#666666"> Hyperion is a true portable weighting in at only 18 pounds. It is light on the eyes with its European amber screen and styling. But heavy on performances with many standard features which are expensive necessities for other personal computers. And all for a price that's less that you'd expect...</font> </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (1984)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> APPLE BUSINESS GRAPHICS</strong></font><br><blockquote>The Apple graphics package was launched in September 1982. It was available for both the Apple II and Apple III.<br><br> Advert said:<br><br> <font color="#666666">As you know, one picture is worth a few thousand numbers.<br> As you may not know, Apple Business Graphics software can generate more types of pictures, in more colours, using more data than any other graphics package... On the monitor of your choice. And on virtually any printer or plotter on the market...</font></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.K. AD. (AUG. 1986)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert says: <br><br><font color="#666666"> In other words, how to pop your office into a shoulder bag and then go out and about.<br> You see the Sharp PC7000 is no ordinary computer. Not only it is light, compact body packed with a much speed and power as most desk top computers, it's also very, very versatile... </font></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> METACARD AD</strong></font><br><blockquote>The MetaCard was the first card allowing an Apple II owner to run IBM-PC programs and MS-DOS, CPM/86 and UCSD operating systems.<br> It used a 5 MHz. 8088 processor, 64 to 128 KB of RAM and a dedicated powed supply unit.<br><br> It was priced at <b>$980</b> (64KB version) and <b>$1,150</b> (128 KB). </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (1987)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Students have a heap particularity which we cared about"</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (DEC. 1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> IN SCHOOLS #1</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT #2</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> ACORN AD. #3 (NOV. 86)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert said:<br><br><font color="#666666"> The BBC Master Compact's educational software, takes children from their first grasp of words and numbers to A-level and beyond.<br> In 84% of U.K. schools, children are already growing up with BBC micros.<br> With a BBC Master Compact at home, your child's ability with computers will progress in leaps and bounds... </font></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT #1</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Carefully, one last time... I compared everything and I offered myself a BBC" <br><br> Lucky guy, he must be rich at more than 6300fr the BBC... At the end of the text we can read : <br><br> "The price : 6300fr maximum. Of course it's not given. More expensive than some (but I had already eliminated them)." !! <br><br> At least they are honest.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> UK ADVERT (APRIL 1985)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> NEW ZEALAND AD #1</strong></font><br><blockquote>This was probably the very first advert of the SC3000 as the pictured machine still was a Japanese version.<br> Notice that the price is in Australian$, probably without the Basic cartridge which is not mentioned in the advert. <br><br> The SC-3000 was very popular in New Zealand in the early to mid 80's. <p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Murray Moffatt</b> from New Zealand </p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD</strong></font><br><blockquote>"From 1 to 16 users"</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> US ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert for Instructor 50, Byte March 1979, Page 45.<p class="petitgris">Thanks to Adam Trinfo for this advert</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> CLOSE-UP</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (JAN. 1980)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>>  GERMAN LEAFLET #2</strong></font><br><blockquote>Preliminary/New product leaflet. For exhibitions only<br><br><br> "The new Personal Computer from SHARP - particularly developed for personal use."<br><br> Note the optional Quick Disc drive.<p class="petitgris">Courtesy of <b>www.sharpmz.org</b></p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>"TO8D, the smart present"<p class="petitgris">Thanks to Yoann Riou for this picture</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> BROCHURE - HAPPY COUPLE</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://www.retrorene.nl/" target="_blank">Retro Rene's Gaming Corner</a> for this picture</p></blockquote>

computer.description:
This computer was probably intended for holding OEM programs thanks to its 8 cartridge slots. Cartridges could be ROM, for programs, or RAM to store data.
The internal O.S. allowed for management of these cartridges, running programs or copying data from one cartridge to another. The content of a cartridge could be sent through the serial interface.
The machine could be powered by either an AC adaptor or an internal NiCd battery.
A V-Marc II was also sold with same features but probably had more RAM.
computer.name: 88a
computer.peripherals: 8 cartridge slots. Built-in 40_80 col. thermal printer
computer.power: External AC adaptor + built-in NiCd battery

shot.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> V-MARC 88A</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to Jean-Michel Jauffrit for this picture</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> KEYBOARD DETAIL</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to Jean-Michel Jauffrit for this picture</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> BOTTOM LABEL</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to Jean-Michel Jauffrit for this picture</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> OS3 CARTRIDGE</strong></font><br><blockquote>This is the cartridge of the V-marc Operating System 3.0<p class="petitgris">Thanks to Jean-Michel Jauffrit for this picture</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> INSIDE THE COVER</strong></font><br><blockquote>Display and keyboard flat cables<p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Jean-Michel Jauffrit</b></p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> V-MARC II</strong></font><br><blockquote>On the surface, the V-marc II is identical to the 88a, apart from the rear label which mentions:<br> <b>V.marc: A Division of Pictorial, Inc.</b> <p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Jean-Michel Jauffrit</b></p></blockquote>
